d'Art et d'Histoire du Judaïsme")

[Purim](/wiki/Purim "Purim") ([Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew
language"): [![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:He-Purim.ogg "About this sound")
[פורים](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c9/He-Purim.ogg "He-
Purim.ogg") ([help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help "Wikipedia:Media
help")·[info](/wiki/File:He-Purim.ogg "File:He-Purim.ogg")) _Pûrîm_
"[lots](/wiki/Cleromancy "Cleromancy")") is a joyous Jewish holiday that
commemorates the deliverance of the [Persian Jews](/wiki/Persian_Jews "Persian
Jews") from the plot of the evil [Haman](/wiki/Haman_\(Bible\) "Haman
\(Bible\)"), who sought to [exterminate](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide") them, as
recorded in the biblical [Book of Esther](/wiki/Book_of_Esther "Book of
Esther"). It is characterized by public recitation of the Book of Esther,
mutual gifts of food and drink, [charity](/wiki/Alms "Alms") to the poor, and
a celebratory meal (Esther 9:22). Other customs include drinking wine, eating
special pastries called [hamantashen](/wiki/Hamantash "Hamantash"), dressing
up in masks and costumes, and organizing carnivals and parties.

Purim has celebrated annually on the 14th of the Hebrew month of
[Adar](/wiki/Adar "Adar"), which occurs in February or March of the Gregorian
calendar.

#### Hanukkah

Main article: [Hanukkah](/wiki/Hanukkah "Hanukkah")

[Hanukkah](/wiki/Hanukkah "Hanukkah") ([Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew
language"): חֲנֻכָּה‎, "dedication") also known as the Festival of Lights, is
an eight-day Jewish holiday that starts on the 25th day of
[Kislev](/wiki/Kislev "Kislev") ([Hebrew calendar](/wiki/Hebrew_calendar
"Hebrew calendar")). The festival is observed in Jewish homes by the kindling
of lights on each of the festival's eight nights, one on the first night, two
on the second night and so on.

The holiday was called Hanukkah (meaning "dedication") because it marks the
re-dedication of the Temple after its desecration by [Antiochus IV
Epiphanes](/wiki/Antiochus_IV_Epiphanes "Antiochus IV Epiphanes").
Spiritually, Hanukkah commemorates the "Miracle of the Oil". According to the
Talmud, at the re-dedication of the [Temple in
Jerusalem](/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem "Temple in Jerusalem") following the
victory of the [Maccabees](/wiki/Maccabees "Maccabees") over the [Seleucid
Empire](/wiki/Seleucid_Empire "Seleucid Empire"), there was only enough
consecrated [oil](/wiki/Oil "Oil") to fuel the eternal flame in the Temple for
one day. Miraculously, the oil burned for eight days – which was the length of
time it took to press, prepare and consecrate new oil.

Hanukkah is not mentioned in the Bible and was never considered a major
holiday in Judaism, but it has become much more visible and widely celebrated
in modern times, mainly because it falls around the same time as Christmas and
has national Jewish overtones that have been emphasized since the
establishment of the State of Israel.

#### Fast days

Main articles: [Tisha B'Av](/wiki/Tisha_B%27Av "Tisha B'Av"), [Seventeenth of
Tamuz](/wiki/Seventeenth_of_Tamuz "Seventeenth of Tamuz"), [10th of
Tevet](/wiki/10th_of_Tevet "10th of Tevet"), and [Tzom
Gedaliah](/wiki/Tzom_Gedaliah "Tzom Gedaliah")

[Tisha B'Av](/wiki/Tisha_B%27Av "Tisha B'Av") ([Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language
"Hebrew language"): תשעה באב‎ or ט׳ באב, "the Ninth of [Av](/wiki/Av_\(month\)
"Av \(month\)")") is a day of mourning and fasting commemorating the
destruction of the [First](/wiki/First_Temple "First Temple") and [Second
Temples](/wiki/Second_Temple "Second Temple"), and in later times, the
[expulsion of the Jews from Spain](/wiki/Alhambra_Decree "Alhambra Decree").

There are three more minor Jewish fast days that commemorate various stages of
the destruction of the Temples. They are the [17th
Tamuz](/wiki/Seventeenth_of_Tamuz "Seventeenth of Tamuz"), the [10th of
Tevet](/wiki/10th_of_Tevet "10th of Tevet") and [Tzom
Gedaliah](/wiki/Tzom_Gedaliah "Tzom Gedaliah") (the 3rd of Tishrei).

#### Israeli holidays

Main articles: [Yom Hashoah](/wiki/Yom_Hashoah "Yom Hashoah"), [Yom
Hazikaron](/wiki/Yom_Hazikaron "Yom Hazikaron"), and [Yom
Ha'atzmaut](/wiki/Yom_Ha%27atzmaut "Yom Ha'atzmaut")

The modern holidays of [Yom Ha-shoah](/wiki/Yom_Ha-shoah "Yom Ha-shoah")
(Holocaust Remembrance Day), [Yom Hazikaron](/wiki/Yom_Hazikaron "Yom
Hazikaron") (Israeli Memorial Day) and [Yom Ha'atzmaut](/wiki/Yom_Ha%27atzmaut
"Yom Ha'atzmaut") (Israeli Independence Day) commemorate the horrors of the
[Holocaust](/wiki/Holocaust "Holocaust"), the fallen soldiers of Israel and
victims of terrorism, and Israeli independence, respectively.

There are some who prefer to commemorate those who were killed in the
Holocaust on the [10th of Tevet](/wiki/Tenth_of_Tevet#Day_of_general_kaddish
"Tenth of Tevet").

### Torah readings

Main article: [Torah reading](/wiki/Torah_reading "Torah reading")

The core of festival and [Shabbat](/wiki/Shabbat "Shabbat") prayer services is
the public reading of the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah"), along with connected
readings from the other books of the [Tanakh](/wiki/Tanakh "Tanakh"), called
[Haftarah](/wiki/Haftarah "Haftarah"). Over the course of a year, the whole
Torah is read, with the cycle starting over in the autumn, on [Simchat
Torah](/wiki/Simchat_Torah "Simchat Torah").

### Synagogues and religious buildings

Main article: [Synagogue](/wiki/Synagogue "Synagogue")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Belz_World_Center_Inside.jpg/220px-
Belz_World_Center_Inside.jpg)](/wiki/File:Belz_World_Center_Inside.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Belz_World_Center_Inside.jpg "Enlarge")

Interior of the [Belz Great Synagogue](/wiki/Belz_Great_Synagogue "Belz Great
Synagogue") in Jerusalem.

Synagogues are Jewish houses of prayer and study. They usually contain
separate rooms for prayer (the main sanctuary), smaller rooms for study, and
often an area for community or educational use. There is no set blueprint for
synagogues and the architectural shapes and interior designs of synagogues
vary greatly. The Reform movement mostly refer to their synagogues as temples.
Some traditional features of a synagogue are:

  * The [ark](/wiki/Ark_\(synagogue\) "Ark \(synagogue\)") (called _aron ha-kodesh_ by [Ashkenazim](/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews "Ashkenazi Jews") and _hekhal_ by [Sephardim](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews")) where the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") scrolls are kept (the ark is often closed with an ornate curtain (_[parochet](/wiki/Parochet "Parochet")_) outside or inside the ark doors);
  * The elevated reader's platform (called _[bimah](/wiki/Bema#Judaism "Bema")_ by Ashkenazim and _tebah_ by Sephardim), where the Torah is read (and services are conducted in Sephardi synagogues);
  * The [eternal light](/wiki/Sanctuary_lamp "Sanctuary lamp") (_ner tamid_), a continually lit lamp or lantern used as a reminder of the constantly lit [menorah](/wiki/Menorah_\(Temple\) "Menorah \(Temple\)") of the [Temple in Jerusalem](/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem "Temple in Jerusalem")
  * The pulpit, or _amud_ , a lectern facing the Ark where the [hazzan](/wiki/Hazzan "Hazzan") or prayer leader stands while praying.

In addition to synagogues, other buildings of significance in Judaism include
[yeshivas](/wiki/Yeshiva "Yeshiva"), or institutions of Jewish learning, and
[mikvahs](/wiki/Mikvah "Mikvah"), which are ritual baths.

### Dietary laws: _kashrut_

Main article: [Kashrut](/wiki/Kashrut "Kashrut")

The Jewish dietary laws are known as _[kashrut](/wiki/Kashrut "Kashrut")_.
Food prepared in accordance with them is termed [kosher](/wiki/Kosher_foods
"Kosher foods"), and food that is not kosher is also known as _treifah_ or
_treif_. People who observe these laws are colloquially said to be "keeping
kosher".[99]

Many of the laws apply to animal-based foods. For example, in order to be
considered kosher, [mammals](/wiki/Mammals "Mammals") must have split
[hooves](/wiki/Hooves "Hooves") and [chew their cud](/wiki/Ruminants
"Ruminants"). The [pig](/wiki/Pig "Pig") is arguably the most well-known
example of a non-kosher animal.[100] Although it has split hooves, it does not
chew its cud.[101] For [seafood](/wiki/Seafood "Seafood") to be kosher, the
animal must have [fins](/wiki/Fins "Fins") and
[scales](/wiki/Scale_\(zoology\) "Scale \(zoology\)"). Certain types of
seafood, such as [shellfish](/wiki/Shellfish "Shellfish"),
[crustaceans](/wiki/Crustaceans "Crustaceans"), and [eels](/wiki/Eel "Eel"),
are therefore considered non-kosher. Concerning birds, a list of non-kosher
species is given in the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah"). The exact
[translations](/wiki/Translations "Translations") of many of the species have
not survived, and some non-kosher birds' identities are no longer certain.
However, [traditions](/wiki/Traditions "Traditions") exist about the _kashrut_
status of a few birds. For example, both [chickens](/wiki/Chickens "Chickens")
and [turkeys](/wiki/Turkeys "Turkeys") are permitted in most communities.
Other types of animals, such as [amphibians](/wiki/Amphibians "Amphibians"),
[reptiles](/wiki/Reptiles "Reptiles"), and most [insects](/wiki/Insects
"Insects"), are prohibited altogether.[99]

In addition to the requirement that the species be considered kosher, meat and
poultry (but not fish) must come from a healthy animal slaughtered in a
process known as _[shechitah](/wiki/Shechitah "Shechitah")_. Without the
proper [slaughtering](/wiki/Animal_slaughter "Animal slaughter") practices
even an otherwise kosher animal will be rendered _treif_. The slaughtering
process is intended to be quick and relatively painless to the animal.
Forbidden parts of animals include the [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood"), some
[fats](/wiki/Fat "Fat"), and the area in and around the [sciatic
nerve](/wiki/Sciatic_nerve "Sciatic nerve").[99]

Jewish law also forbids the consumption of meat and dairy products together.
The waiting period between eating meat and eating dairy varies by the order in
which they are consumed and by community, and can extend for up to six hours.
Based on the Biblical injunction against cooking a kid in its mother's milk,
this rule is mostly derived from the [Oral Torah](/wiki/Oral_Torah "Oral
Torah"), the [Talmud](/wiki/Talmud "Talmud") and [Rabbinic
law](/wiki/Rabbinic_law "Rabbinic law").[99] Chicken and other kosher birds
are considered the same as meat under the laws of _kashrut_ , but the
prohibition is Rabbinic, not Biblical.[102]

The use of [dishes](/wiki/Dishware "Dishware"), serving utensils, and
[ovens](/wiki/Oven "Oven") may make food _treif_ that would otherwise be
kosher. Utensils that have been used to prepare non-kosher food, or dishes
that have held meat and are now used for dairy products, render the food
_treif_ under certain conditions.[99]

Furthermore, all [Orthodox](/wiki/Orthodox_Judaism "Orthodox Judaism") and
some [Conservative](/wiki/Conservative_Judaism "Conservative Judaism")
authorities forbid the consumption of processed [grape](/wiki/Grape "Grape")
products made by non-Jews, due to ancient [pagan](/wiki/Pagan "Pagan")
practices of using wine in rituals.[99] Some Conservative authorities permit
wine and grape juice made without rabbinic supervision.[103]

The [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") does not give specific reasons for most of
the laws of _kashrut_.[99] However, a number of explanations have been
offered, including maintaining ritual purity, teaching impulse control,
encouraging obedience to God, improving health, reducing [cruelty to
animals](/wiki/Cruelty_to_animals "Cruelty to animals") and preserving the
distinctness of the Jewish community.[104] The various categories of dietary
laws may have developed for different reasons, and some may exist for multiple
reasons. For example, people are forbidden from consuming the blood of birds
and mammals because, according to the Torah, this is where animal souls are
contained.[105] In contrast, the Torah forbids Israelites from eating non-
kosher species because "they are unclean".[106] The [Kabbalah](/wiki/Kabbalah
"Kabbalah") describes sparks of holiness that are released by the act of
eating kosher foods, but are too tightly bound in non-kosher foods to be
released by eating.[107]

Survival concerns supersede all the laws of _kashrut_ , as they do for most
[halakhot](/wiki/Halakha "Halakha").[108][109]

### Laws of ritual purity

Main article: [Tumah](/wiki/Tumah "Tumah")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/%D0%A8%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B0_-_Shabbat_matchbox_holder.jpg/250px-%D0%A8%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B0_-_Shabbat_matchbox_holder.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A8%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B0_-_Shabbat_matchbox_holder.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%D0%A8%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B0_-_Shabbat_matchbox_holder.jpg
"Enlarge")

A silver matchbox holder for ritual use on [Shabbat](/wiki/Shabbat "Shabbat")
with inscription in [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language")

The [Tanakh](/wiki/Tanakh "Tanakh") describes circumstances in which a person
who is _tahor_ or ritually pure may become _tamei_ or ritually impure. Some of
these circumstances are contact with human [corpses](/wiki/Corpses "Corpses")
or [graves](/wiki/Grave_\(burial\) "Grave \(burial\)"), seminal flux, vaginal
flux, [menstruation](/wiki/Menstruation "Menstruation"), and contact with
people who have become impure from any of these.[110][111] In Rabbinic
Judaism, [Kohanim](/wiki/Kohanim "Kohanim"), members of the hereditary
[caste](/wiki/Caste "Caste") that served as [priests](/wiki/Priests "Priests")
in the time of the Temple, are mostly restricted from entering grave sites and
touching dead bodies.[112] During the Temple period, such priests
([Kohanim](/wiki/Kohanim "Kohanim")) were required to eat their bread offering
([Terumah](/wiki/Terumah "Terumah")) in a state of ritual purity, which laws
eventually led to more rigid laws being enacted, such as [hand-
washing](/wiki/Handwashing_in_Judaism "Handwashing in Judaism") which became a
requisite of all Jews before consuming ordinary bread.

#### Family purity

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Fauteuil_de_circoncision_%28%22Fauteuil_d%27Elie%22%29.jpg/250px-
Fauteuil_de_circoncision_%28%22Fauteuil_d%27Elie%22%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fauteuil_de_circoncision_\(%22Fauteuil_d%27Elie%22\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fauteuil_de_circoncision_\(%22Fauteuil_d%27Elie%22\).jpg
"Enlarge")

18th-century circumcision chair [Museum of Jewish Art and
History](/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Art_et_d%27Histoire_du_Juda%C3%AFsme "Musée
d'Art et d'Histoire du Judaïsme")

Main article: [Niddah](/wiki/Niddah "Niddah")

An important subcategory of the ritual purity laws relates to the segregation
of menstruating [women](/wiki/Women "Women"). These laws are also known as
_[niddah](/wiki/Niddah "Niddah")_ , literally "separation", or family purity.
Vital aspects of halakha for traditionally observant Jews, they are not
usually followed by Jews in liberal denominations.[113]

Especially in [Orthodox Judaism](/wiki/Orthodox_Judaism "Orthodox Judaism"),
the Biblical laws are augmented by Rabbinical injunctions. For example, the
[Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") mandates that a woman in her normal menstrual
period must abstain from [sexual intercourse](/wiki/Sexual_intercourse "Sexual
intercourse") for seven days. A woman whose menstruation is prolonged must
continue to abstain for seven more days after bleeding has stopped.[110] The
Rabbis conflated ordinary _niddah_ with this extended menstrual period, known
in the Torah as _[zavah](/wiki/Zavah "Zavah")_ , and mandated that a woman may
not have sexual intercourse with her [husband](/wiki/Husband "Husband") from
the time she begins her [menstrual](/wiki/Menstrual_cycle "Menstrual cycle")
flow until seven days after it ends. In addition, [Rabbinical
law](/wiki/Rabbinical_law "Rabbinical law") forbids the
[husband](/wiki/Husband "Husband") from touching or sharing a bed with his
wife during this period. Afterwards, purification can occur in a ritual bath
called a [mikveh](/wiki/Mikveh "Mikveh").[113]

Traditional [Ethiopian Jews](/wiki/Ethiopian_Jews "Ethiopian Jews") keep
menstruating women in separate [huts](/wiki/Huts "Huts") and, similar to
[Karaite practice](/wiki/Karaite_Judaism "Karaite Judaism"), do not allow
menstruating women into their [temples](/wiki/Temples "Temples") because of a
temple's special sanctity. Emigration to [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") and
the influence of other Jewish denominations have led to Ethiopian Jews
adopting more normative Jewish practices.[114][115]

### Life-cycle events

Life-cycle events, or [rites of passage](/wiki/Rites_of_passage "Rites of
passage"), occur throughout a Jew's life that serves to strengthen Jewish
identity and bind him/her to the entire community.

  * [Brit milah](/wiki/Brit_milah "Brit milah") – Welcoming male babies into the covenant through the rite of [circumcision](/wiki/Circumcision "Circumcision") on their eighth day of life. The baby boy is also given his Hebrew name in the ceremony. A naming ceremony intended as a parallel ritual for girls, named _[zeved habat](/wiki/Zeved_habat "Zeved habat")_ or brit bat, enjoys limited popularity.
  * [Bar mitzvah and Bat mitzvah](/wiki/Bar_Mitzvah_/_Bat_Mitzvah "Bar Mitzvah / Bat Mitzvah") – This passage from childhood to adulthood takes place when a female Jew is twelve and a male Jew is thirteen years old among Orthodox and some Conservative congregations. In the Reform movement, both girls and boys have their bat/bar mitzvah at age thirteen. This is often commemorated by having the new adults, male only in the Orthodox tradition, lead the congregation in prayer and publicly read a "portion" of the Torah.
  * [Marriage](/wiki/Jewish_views_of_marriage "Jewish views of marriage") – Marriage is an extremely important lifecycle event. A wedding takes place under a _[chuppah](/wiki/Chuppah "Chuppah")_ , or wedding canopy, which symbolizes a happy house. At the end of the ceremony, the groom breaks a glass with his foot, symbolizing the continuous mourning for the destruction of the Temple, and the scattering of the Jewish people.
  * [Death and Mourning](/wiki/Bereavement_in_Judaism "Bereavement in Judaism") – Judaism has a multi-staged [mourning](/wiki/Mourning "Mourning") practice. The first stage is called the [shiva](/wiki/Shiva_\(Judaism\) "Shiva \(Judaism\)") (literally "seven", observed for one week) during which it is traditional to sit at home and be comforted by friends and family, the second is the _shloshim_ (observed for one month) and for those who have lost one of their parents, there is a third stage, _avelut yud bet chodesh_ , which is observed for eleven months.

## Community leadership

### Classical priesthood

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Jewish_Children_with_their_Teacher_in_Samarkand.jpg/220px-
Jewish_Children_with_their_Teacher_in_Samarkand.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jewish_Children_with_their_Teacher_in_Samarkand.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jewish_Children_with_their_Teacher_in_Samarkand.jpg "Enlarge")

Jewish students with their teacher in [Samarkand](/wiki/Samarkand
"Samarkand"), [Uzbekistan](/wiki/Uzbekistan "Uzbekistan") c. 1910.

The role of the priesthood in Judaism has significantly diminished since the
destruction of the [Second Temple](/wiki/Second_Temple "Second Temple") in 70
CE when priests attended to the Temple and sacrifices. The priesthood is an
inherited position, and although priests no longer have any but ceremonial
duties, they are still honored in many Jewish communities. Many Orthodox
Jewish communities believe that they will be needed again for a future [Third
Temple](/wiki/Third_Temple "Third Temple") and need to remain in readiness for
future duty.

  * [Kohen](/wiki/Kohen "Kohen") (priest) – patrilineal descendant of [Aaron](/wiki/Aaron "Aaron"), brother of [Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses"). In the Temple, the _kohanim_ were charged with performing the sacrifices. Today, a Kohen is the first one called up at the reading of the Torah, performs the [Priestly Blessing](/wiki/Priestly_Blessing "Priestly Blessing"), as well as complying with other unique laws and ceremonies, including the ceremony of redemption of the first-born.
  * Levi ([Levite](/wiki/Levite "Levite")) – Patrilineal descendant of [Levi](/wiki/Levi "Levi") the son of [Jacob](/wiki/Jacob "Jacob"). In the [Temple in Jerusalem](/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem "Temple in Jerusalem"), the levites sang [Psalms](/wiki/Psalms "Psalms"), performed construction, maintenance, janitorial, and guard duties, assisted the priests, and sometimes interpreted the law and Temple ritual to the public. Today, a Levite is called up second to the reading of the Torah.

### Prayer leaders

From the time of the [Mishnah](/wiki/Mishnah "Mishnah") and
[Talmud](/wiki/Talmud "Talmud") to the present, Judaism has required
specialists or authorities for the practice of very few rituals or ceremonies.
A Jew can fulfill most requirements for prayer by himself. Some
activities—reading the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") and _haftarah_ (a
supplementary portion from the Prophets or Writings), the prayer for mourners,
the blessings for bridegroom and bride, the complete grace after meals—require
a _[minyan](/wiki/Minyan "Minyan")_ , the presence of ten Jews.

The most common professional clergy in a [synagogue](/wiki/Synagogue
"Synagogue") are:

  * [Rabbi](/wiki/Rabbi "Rabbi") of a congregation – Jewish scholar who is charged with answering the legal questions of a congregation. This role requires ordination by the congregation's preferred authority (i.e., from a respected Orthodox rabbi or, if the congregation is Conservative or Reform, from academic seminaries). A congregation does not necessarily require a rabbi. Some congregations have a rabbi but also allow members of the congregation to act as _shatz_ or _baal kriyah_ (see below). 
    * Hassidic _[Rebbe](/wiki/Rebbe "Rebbe")_ – rabbi who is the head of a [Hasidic](/wiki/Hasidic_Judaism "Hasidic Judaism") dynasty.
  * [Hazzan](/wiki/Hazzan "Hazzan") (note: the "h" denotes [voiceless pharyngeal fricative](/wiki/Voiceless_pharyngeal_fricative "Voiceless pharyngeal fricative")) (cantor) – a trained vocalist who acts as _shatz_. Chosen for a good voice, knowledge of traditional tunes, understanding of the meaning of the prayers and sincerity in reciting them. A congregation does not need to have a dedicated hazzan.

Jewish prayer services do involve two specified roles, which are sometimes,
but not always, filled by a rabbi or hazzan in many congregations. In other
congregations these roles are filled on an ad-hoc basis by members of the
congregation who lead portions of services on a rotating basis:

  * Shaliach tzibur or _Shatz_ (leader—literally "agent" or "representative"—of the congregation) leads those assembled in prayer and sometimes prays on behalf of the community. When a _shatz_ recites a prayer on behalf of the congregation, he is _not_ acting as an intermediary but rather as a facilitator. The entire congregation participates in the recital of such prayers by saying _amen_ at their conclusion; it is with this act that the _shatz 's_ prayer becomes the prayer of the congregation. Any adult capable of reciting the prayers clearly may act as _shatz_. In Orthodox congregations and some Conservative congregations, only men can be prayer leaders, but all [Progressive](/wiki/Progressive_Judaism "Progressive Judaism") communities now allow women to serve in this function.
  * The Baal kriyah or _baal koreh_ (master of the reading) reads the weekly [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") portion. The requirements for being the _baal kriyah_ are the same as those for the _shatz_. These roles are not mutually exclusive. The same person is often qualified to fill more than one role and often does. Often there are several people capable of filling these roles and different services (or parts of services) will be led by each.

Many congregations, especially larger ones, also rely on a:

  * [Gabbai](/wiki/Gabbai "Gabbai") (sexton) – Calls people up to the Torah, appoints the _shatz_ for each prayer session if there is no standard _shatz_ , and makes certain that the synagogue is kept clean and supplied.

The three preceding positions are usually voluntary and considered an honor.
Since the [Enlightenment](/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age of Enlightenment")
large synagogues have often adopted the practice of hiring rabbis and hazzans
to act as _shatz_ and _baal kriyah_ , and this is still typically the case in
many Conservative and Reform congregations. However, in most Orthodox
synagogues these positions are filled by laypeople on a rotating or ad-hoc
basis. Although most congregations hire one or more Rabbis, the use of a
professional hazzan is generally declining in American congregations, and the
use of professionals for other offices is rarer still.

### Specialized religious roles

  * _[Dayan](/wiki/Beth_din#Officers_of_a_beth_din "Beth din")_ (judge) – An ordained rabbi with special legal training who belongs to a _[beth din](/wiki/Beth_din "Beth din")_ (rabbinical court). In Israel, religious courts handle marriage and divorce cases, conversion and financial disputes in the Jewish community.
  * [Mohel](/wiki/Mohel "Mohel") (circumciser) – An expert in the laws of circumcision who has received training from a previously qualified _mohel_ and performs the _[brit milah](/wiki/Brit_milah "Brit milah")_ (circumcision).
  * [Shochet](/wiki/Shechita "Shechita") (ritual slaughterer) – In order for meat to be kosher, it must be slaughtered by a _shochet_ who is an expert in the laws of kashrut and has been trained by another _shochet._
  * [Sofer](/wiki/Sofer_\(scribe\) "Sofer \(scribe\)") (scribe) – [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") scrolls, _[tefillin](/wiki/Tefillin "Tefillin")_ (phylacteries), _[mezuzot](/wiki/Mezuzah "Mezuzah")_ (scrolls put on doorposts), and _gittin_ (bills of divorce) must be written by a _sofer_ who is an expert in Hebrew calligraphy and has undergone rigorous training in the laws of writing sacred texts.
  * [Rosh yeshiva](/wiki/Rosh_yeshiva "Rosh yeshiva") – A Torah scholar who runs a [yeshiva](/wiki/Yeshiva "Yeshiva").
  * [Mashgiach](/wiki/Mashgiach_ruchani "Mashgiach ruchani") of a yeshiva – Depending on which yeshiva, might either be the person responsible for ensuring attendance and proper conduct, or even supervise the emotional and spiritual welfare of the students and give lectures on [mussar](/wiki/Mussar_movement "Mussar movement") (Jewish ethics).
  * [Mashgiach](/wiki/Mashgiach "Mashgiach") – Supervises manufacturers of kosher food, importers, caterers and restaurants to ensure that the food is kosher. Must be an expert in the laws of [kashrut](/wiki/Kashrut "Kashrut") and trained by a rabbi, if not a rabbi himself.

## History

Main article: [Jewish history](/wiki/Jewish_history "Jewish history")

This section is about the history of Judaism. For the book on Ancient Judaism,
see [Ancient Judaism (book)](/wiki/Ancient_Judaism_\(book\) "Ancient Judaism
\(book\)").

### Origins

Main article: [Origins of Judaism](/wiki/Origins_of_Judaism "Origins of
Judaism")

Further information: [Ancient Canaanite
religion](/wiki/Ancient_Canaanite_religion "Ancient Canaanite religion") and
[Ancient Semitic religion](/wiki/Ancient_Semitic_religion "Ancient Semitic
religion")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Duraeuropa-1-.gif/220px-
Duraeuropa-1-.gif)](/wiki/File:Duraeuropa-1-.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Duraeuropa-1-.gif "Enlarge")

Scenes from the [Book of Esther](/wiki/Book_of_Esther "Book of Esther")
decorate the [Dura-Europos synagogue](/wiki/Dura-Europos_synagogue "Dura-
Europos synagogue") dating from 244 CE

At its core, the Tanakh is an account of the [Israelites](/wiki/Israelite
"Israelite")' relationship with [God](/wiki/God "God") from their earliest
history until the building of the [Second Temple](/wiki/Second_Temple "Second
Temple") (c. 535 BCE). [Abraham](/wiki/Abraham "Abraham") is hailed as the
first [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrews "Hebrews") and the father of the Jewish people.
As a reward for his act of faith in one God, he was promised that
[Isaac](/wiki/Isaac "Isaac"), his second son, would inherit the [Land of
Israel](/wiki/Land_of_Israel "Land of Israel") (then called
[Canaan](/wiki/Canaan "Canaan")). Later, the descendants of Isaac's son
[Jacob](/wiki/Jacob "Jacob") were enslaved in [Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt
"Ancient Egypt"), and God commanded [Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses") to lead [the
Exodus](/wiki/The_Exodus "The Exodus") from Egypt. At [Mount
Sinai](/wiki/Biblical_Mount_Sinai "Biblical Mount Sinai"), they received the
[Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah")—the five books of Moses. These books, together
with [Nevi'im](/wiki/Nevi%27im "Nevi'im") and [Ketuvim](/wiki/Ketuvim
"Ketuvim") are known as _Torah Shebikhtav_ as opposed to the [Oral
Torah](/wiki/Oral_Torah "Oral Torah"), which refers to the Mishnah and the
Talmud. Eventually, God led them to the [land of Israel](/wiki/Land_of_Israel
"Land of Israel") where the [tabernacle](/wiki/Tabernacle "Tabernacle") was
planted in the city of [Shiloh](/wiki/Shiloh_\(Biblical\) "Shiloh
\(Biblical\)") for over 300 years to rally the nation against attacking
enemies. As time went on, the spiritual level of the nation declined to the
point that God allowed the [Philistines](/wiki/Philistines "Philistines") to
capture the tabernacle. The people of Israel then told
[Samuel](/wiki/Samuel_\(Bible\) "Samuel \(Bible\)") the
[prophet](/wiki/Prophet "Prophet") that they needed to be governed by a
permanent king, and Samuel appointed [Saul](/wiki/Saul_the_King "Saul the
King") to be their King. When the people pressured Saul into going against a
command conveyed to him by Samuel, God told Samuel to appoint
[David](/wiki/David "David") in his stead.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Western_wall_jerusalem_night.jpg/220px-
Western_wall_jerusalem_night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Western_wall_jerusalem_night.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Western_wall_jerusalem_night.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Western Wall](/wiki/Western_Wall "Western Wall") in
[Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem") is a remnant of the wall encircling
the [Second Temple](/wiki/Second_Temple "Second Temple"). The [Temple
Mount](/wiki/Temple_Mount "Temple Mount") is the holiest site in Judaism.

Once King David was established, he told the prophet
[Nathan](/wiki/Nathan_\(prophet\) "Nathan \(prophet\)") that he would like to
build a permanent temple, and as a reward for his actions, God promised David
that he would allow his son, [Solomon](/wiki/Solomon "Solomon"), to build the
[First Temple](/wiki/Solomon%27s_Temple "Solomon's Temple") and the throne
would never depart from his children.

Rabbinic tradition holds that the details and interpretation of the law, which
are called the _[Oral Torah](/wiki/Oral_Torah "Oral Torah")_ or _[oral
law](/wiki/Oral_law#Oral_law_in_Judaism "Oral law")_ , were originally an
unwritten tradition based upon what God told Moses on Mount Sinai. However, as
the persecutions of the Jews increased and the details were in danger of being
forgotten, these oral laws were recorded by [Rabbi](/wiki/Rabbi "Rabbi")
[Judah HaNasi](/wiki/Judah_HaNasi "Judah HaNasi") (Judah the Prince) in the
[Mishnah](/wiki/Mishnah "Mishnah"), redacted _circa_ 200 CE. The
[Talmud](/wiki/Talmud "Talmud") was a compilation of both the Mishnah and the
[Gemara](/wiki/Gemara "Gemara"), rabbinic commentaries redacted over the next
three centuries. The Gemara originated in two major centers of Jewish
scholarship, [Palestine](/wiki/Talmudic_Academies_in_Syria_Palaestina
"Talmudic Academies in Syria Palaestina") and
[Babylonia](/wiki/Talmudic_Academies_in_Babylonia "Talmudic Academies in
Babylonia").[116] Correspondingly, two bodies of analysis developed, and two
works of Talmud were created. The older compilation is called the [Jerusalem
Talmud](/wiki/Jerusalem_Talmud "Jerusalem Talmud"). It was compiled sometime
during the 4th century in
[Palestine](/wiki/Talmudic_Academies_in_Syria_Palaestina "Talmudic Academies
in Syria Palaestina").[116] The Babylonian Talmud was compiled from
discussions in the houses of study by the scholars [Ravina I](/wiki/Ravina_I
"Ravina I"), [Ravina II](/wiki/Ravina_II "Ravina II"), and [Rav
Ashi](/wiki/Rav_Ashi "Rav Ashi") by 500 CE, although it continued to be edited
later.

Some critical scholars oppose the view that the sacred texts, including the
[Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Tanakh "Tanakh"), were divinely inspired. Many of these
scholars accept the general principles of the [documentary
hypothesis](/wiki/Documentary_hypothesis "Documentary hypothesis") and suggest
that the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") consists of inconsistent texts edited
together in a way that calls attention to divergent accounts.[117][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_][118][119]
Many suggest that during the First Temple period, the people of Israel
believed that each nation had its own god, but that their god was superior to
other gods.[120][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_][121][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] Some
suggest that strict monotheism developed during the Babylonian Exile, perhaps
in reaction to [Zoroastrian](/wiki/Zoroastrian "Zoroastrian") dualism.[122] In
this view, it was only by the [Hellenic period](/wiki/Hellenic_period
"Hellenic period") that most Jews came to believe that their god was the only
god and that the notion of a clearly bounded Jewish nation identical with the
Jewish religion formed.[123]

[John Day](/wiki/John_Day_\(Old_Testament_scholar\) "John Day \(Old Testament
scholar\)") argues that the origins of biblical [Yahweh](/wiki/Yahweh
"Yahweh"), [El](/wiki/El_\(deity\) "El \(deity\)"), [Asherah](/wiki/Asherah
"Asherah"), and [Ba'al](/wiki/Ba%27al "Ba'al"), may be rooted in earlier
[Canaanite religion](/wiki/Canaanite_religion "Canaanite religion"), which was
centered on a pantheon of gods much like the [Greek
pantheon](/wiki/Greek_pantheon "Greek pantheon").[124]

### Antiquity

Main articles: [Ancient Israel and Judah](/wiki/Ancient_Israel_and_Judah
"Ancient Israel and Judah"), [Babylonian captivity](/wiki/Babylonian_captivity
"Babylonian captivity"), [Hellenistic Judaism](/wiki/Hellenistic_Judaism
"Hellenistic Judaism"), [Hasmonean Kingdom](/wiki/Hasmonean_Kingdom "Hasmonean
Kingdom"), [Iudaea Province](/wiki/Iudaea_Province "Iudaea Province"), and
[Bar Kokhba revolt](/wiki/Bar_Kokhba_revolt "Bar Kokhba revolt")

According to the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible"), the
[United Monarchy](/wiki/United_Monarchy "United Monarchy") was established
under [Saul](/wiki/Saul_the_King "Saul the King") and continued under [King
David](/wiki/King_David "King David") and [Solomon](/wiki/Solomon "Solomon")
with its capital in [Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem"). After Solomon's
reign, the nation split into two kingdoms, the [Kingdom of
Israel](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_\(Samaria\) "Kingdom of Israel \(Samaria\)")
(in the north) and the [Kingdom of Judah](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah "Kingdom of
Judah") (in the south). The Kingdom of Israel was conquered by the
[Assyrian](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria") ruler [Sargon II](/wiki/Sargon_II "Sargon
II") in the late 8th century BCE with many people from the capital Samaria
being taken captive to Media and the [Khabur River](/wiki/Khabur_\(Euphrates\)
"Khabur \(Euphrates\)") valley. The [Kingdom of Judah](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah
"Kingdom of Judah") continued as an independent state until it was conquered
by a Babylonian army in the early 6th century BCE, destroying the [First
Temple](/wiki/First_Temple "First Temple") that was at the center of ancient
Jewish worship. The Judean elite was exiled to [Babylonia](/wiki/Babylonia
"Babylonia") and this is regarded as the first Jewish Diaspora. Later many of
them returned to their homeland after the subsequent conquest of Babylonia by
the [Persians](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire "Achaemenid Empire") seventy years
later, a period known as the [Babylonian Captivity](/wiki/Babylonian_Captivity
"Babylonian Captivity"). A new [Second Temple](/wiki/Second_Temple "Second
Temple") was constructed, and old religious practices were resumed.

During the early years of the Second Temple, the highest religious authority
was a council known as the Great Assembly, led by Ezra of the Book of Ezra.
Among other accomplishments of the Great Assembly, the last books of the Bible
were written at this time and the canon sealed.

[Hellenistic Judaism](/wiki/Hellenistic_Judaism "Hellenistic Judaism") spread
to [Ptolemaic Egypt](/wiki/Ptolemaic_Egypt "Ptolemaic Egypt") from the 3rd
century BCE. After [the Great Revolt](/wiki/First_Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_War
"First Jewish–Roman War") (66–73 CE), the Romans destroyed the Temple.
[Hadrian](/wiki/Hadrian "Hadrian") built a pagan idol on the Temple grounds
and prohibited circumcision; these acts of ethnocide provoked the [Bar Kokhba
revolt](/wiki/Bar_Kokhba_revolt "Bar Kokhba revolt") 132–136 CE after which
the Romans banned the study of the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") and the
celebration of Jewish holidays, and forcibly removed virtually all Jews from
Judea. In 200 CE, however, Jews were granted Roman citizenship and Judaism was
recognized as a _[religio licita](/wiki/Religio_licita "Religio licita")_
("legitimate religion") until the rise of [Gnosticism](/wiki/Gnosticism
"Gnosticism") and [Early Christianity](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early
Christianity") in the fourth century.

Following the destruction of Jerusalem and the expulsion of the Jews, Jewish
worship stopped being centrally organized around the Temple, prayer took the
place of sacrifice, and worship was rebuilt around the community (represented
by a minimum of ten adult men) and the establishment of the authority of
rabbis who acted as teachers and leaders of individual communities (see
[Jewish diaspora](/wiki/Jewish_diaspora "Jewish diaspora")).

### Historical Jewish groupings (to 1700)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Parochet_of_Beth_Jakov_Macedonia.jpg/220px-
Parochet_of_Beth_Jakov_Macedonia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parochet_of_Beth_Jakov_Macedonia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Parochet_of_Beth_Jakov_Macedonia.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Torah Ark](/wiki/Torah_Ark "Torah Ark") of the Beth Jakov synagogue in
[Macedonia](/wiki/Republic_of_Macedonia "Republic of Macedonia")

Around the 1st century CE, there were several small Jewish sects: the
[Pharisees](/wiki/Pharisees "Pharisees"), [Sadducees](/wiki/Sadducees
"Sadducees"), [Zealots](/wiki/Zealots "Zealots"), [Essenes](/wiki/Essenes
"Essenes"), and [Christians](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early Christianity").
After the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE, these sects
vanished.[125] [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") survived, but
by breaking with Judaism and [becoming a separate
religion](/wiki/Schism_\(religion\) "Schism \(religion\)"); the
[Pharisees](/wiki/Pharisees "Pharisees") survived but in the form of [Rabbinic
Judaism](/wiki/Rabbinic_Judaism "Rabbinic Judaism") (today, known simply as
"Judaism"). The [Sadducees](/wiki/Sadducees "Sadducees") rejected the [divine
inspiration](/wiki/Revelation "Revelation") of the [Prophets](/wiki/Nevi%27im
"Nevi'im") and the [Writings](/wiki/Ketuvim "Ketuvim"), relying only on the
[Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") as divinely inspired. Consequently, a number of
other core tenets of the Pharisees' belief system (which became the basis for
modern Judaism), were also dismissed by the Sadducees. (The
[Samaritans](/wiki/Samaritans "Samaritans") practiced a similar religion,
which is traditionally considered separate from Judaism.)

Like the Sadducees who relied only on the Torah, some Jews in the 8th and 9th
centuries rejected the authority and divine inspiration of the [oral
law](/wiki/Oral_law "Oral law") as recorded in the [Mishnah](/wiki/Mishnah
"Mishnah") (and developed by later rabbis in the two [Talmuds](/wiki/Talmud
"Talmud")), relying instead only upon the [Tanakh](/wiki/Tanakh "Tanakh").
These included the Isunians, the Yudganites, the [Malikites](/wiki/Malikites
"Malikites"), and others. They soon developed oral traditions of their own,
which differed from the rabbinic traditions, and eventually formed the
[Karaite](/wiki/Karaism "Karaism") sect. Karaites exist in small numbers
today, mostly living in Israel. Rabbinical and Karaite Jews each hold that the
others are Jews, but that the other faith is erroneous.

Over a long time, Jews formed distinct ethnic groups in several different
geographic areas—amongst others, the [Ashkenazi Jews](/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews
"Ashkenazi Jews") (of [central](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") and
[Eastern Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe")), the [Sephardi
Jews](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") (of Spain,
[Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal"), and [North Africa](/wiki/North_Africa
"North Africa")), the [Beta Israel](/wiki/Beta_Israel "Beta Israel") of
[Ethiopia](/wiki/Ethiopia "Ethiopia"), and the [Yemenite
Jews](/wiki/Yemenite_Jews "Yemenite Jews") from the southern tip of the
[Arabian Peninsula](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula "Arabian Peninsula"). Many of
these groups have developed differences in their prayers, traditions and
accepted canons; however, these distinctions are mainly the result of their
being formed at some cultural distance from normative (rabbinic) Judaism,
rather than based on any doctrinal dispute.

### Persecutions

Main articles: [Persecution of Jews](/wiki/Persecution_of_Jews "Persecution of
Jews"), [Antisemitism](/wiki/Antisemitism "Antisemitism"), and [History of
antisemitism](/wiki/History_of_antisemitism "History of antisemitism")

[Antisemitism](/wiki/Antisemitism "Antisemitism") arose during the [Middle
Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), in the form of persecutions,
[pogroms](/wiki/Pogrom "Pogrom"), [forced conversions](/wiki/Forced_conversion
"Forced conversion"), expulsions, social restrictions and
[ghettoization](/wiki/Ghetto "Ghetto").

This was different in quality from the repressions of Jews which had occurred
in ancient times. Ancient repressions were politically motivated and Jews were
treated the same as members of other ethnic groups. With the rise of the
Churches, the main motive for attacks on Jews changed from politics to
religion and the religious motive for such attacks was specifically derived
from Christian views about Jews and Judaism.[126] During the [Middle
Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), Jewish people who lived under Muslim
rule generally experienced tolerance and integration,[127] but there were
occasional outbreaks of violence like [Almohad's
persecutions](/wiki/Almohads#Status_of_non-Muslims "Almohads").[128]

### Hasidism

Main article: [Hasidic Judaism](/wiki/Hasidic_Judaism "Hasidic Judaism")

Hasidic Judaism was founded by [Yisroel ben
Eliezer](/wiki/Yisroel_ben_Eliezer_\(The_Baal_Shem_Tov\) "Yisroel ben Eliezer
\(The Baal Shem Tov\)") (1700–1760), also known as the _Ba 'al Shem Tov_ (or
_Besht_). It originated in a time of persecution of the Jewish people when
European Jews had turned inward to Talmud study; many felt that most
expressions of Jewish life had become too "academic", and that they no longer
had any emphasis on spirituality or joy. Its adherents favored small and
informal gatherings called [Shtiebel](/wiki/Shtiebel "Shtiebel"), which, in
contrast to a traditional synagogue, could be used both as a place of worship
and for celebrations involving dancing, eating, and socializing.[129] Ba'al
Shem Tov's disciples attracted many followers; they themselves established
numerous Hasidic sects across Europe. Unlike other religions, which typically
expanded through word of mouth or by use of print, Hasidism spread largely
owing to [Tzadiks](/wiki/Tzadik "Tzadik"), who used their influence to
encourage others to follow the movement. Hasidism appealed to many Europeans
because it was easy to learn, did not require full immediate commitment, and
presented a compelling spectacle.[130] Hasidic Judaism eventually became the
way of life for many Jews in Eastern Europe. Waves of Jewish immigration in
the 1880s carried it to the United States. The movement itself claims to be
nothing new, but a _refreshment_ of original Judaism. As some have put it: _"
they merely re-emphasized that which the generations had lost"_. Nevertheless,
early on there was a serious schism between Hasidic and non-Hasidic Jews.
European Jews who rejected the Hasidic movement were dubbed by the Hasidim as
[Misnagdim](/wiki/Misnagdim "Misnagdim"), (lit. "opponents"). Some of the
reasons for the rejection of Hasidic Judaism were the exuberance of Hasidic
worship, its deviation from tradition in ascribing infallibility and miracles
to their leaders, and the concern that it might become a messianic sect. Over
time differences between the Hasidim and their opponents have slowly
diminished and both groups are now considered part of [Haredi
Judaism](/wiki/Haredi_Judaism "Haredi Judaism").

### The Enlightenment and new religious movements

Main articles: [Haskalah](/wiki/Haskalah "Haskalah") and [Jewish religious
movements](/wiki/Jewish_religious_movements "Jewish religious movements")

In the late 18th century CE, Europe was swept by a group of intellectual,
social and political movements known as the
[Enlightenment](/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age of Enlightenment"). The
Enlightenment led to reductions in the European laws that prohibited Jews to
interact with the wider secular world, thus allowing Jews access to secular
education and experience. A parallel Jewish movement,
[Haskalah](/wiki/Haskalah "Haskalah") or the "Jewish Enlightenment", began,
especially in [Central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") and
[Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe"), in response to both
the Enlightenment and these new freedoms. It placed an emphasis on integration
with secular society and a pursuit of non-religious knowledge through reason.
With the promise of political emancipation, many Jews saw no reason to
continue to observe Jewish law and increasing numbers of Jews assimilated into
Christian Europe. Modern religious movements of Judaism all formed in reaction
to this trend.

In [Central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe"), followed by [Great
Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain") and the United States, [Reform
(or Liberal) Judaism](/wiki/Reform_Judaism "Reform Judaism") developed,
relaxing legal obligations (especially those that limited Jewish relations
with non-Jews), emulating [Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") decorum
in prayer, and emphasizing the ethical values of Judaism's Prophetic
tradition. [Modern Orthodox Judaism](/wiki/Modern_Orthodox_Judaism "Modern
Orthodox Judaism") developed in reaction to Reform Judaism, by leaders who
argued that Jews could participate in public life as citizens equal to
Christians while maintaining the observance of Jewish law. Meanwhile, in the
United States, wealthy Reform Jews helped European scholars, who were Orthodox
in practice but critical (and skeptical) in their study of the Bible and
Talmud, to establish a seminary to train rabbis for immigrants from Eastern
Europe. These left-wing Orthodox rabbis were joined by right-wing Reform
rabbis who felt that Jewish law should not be entirely abandoned, to form the
[Conservative movement](/wiki/Conservative_Judaism "Conservative Judaism").
Orthodox Jews who opposed the Haskalah formed [Haredi Orthodox
Judaism](/wiki/Haredi_Orthodox_Judaism "Haredi Orthodox Judaism"). After
massive movements of Jews following [The Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The
Holocaust") and the creation of [the state of Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel"),
these movements have competed for followers from among traditional Jews in or
from other countries.

### Spectrum of observance

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/KnesetEliyahooSynagogue.JPG/220px-
KnesetEliyahooSynagogue.JPG)](/wiki/File:KnesetEliyahooSynagogue.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:KnesetEliyahooSynagogue.JPG "Enlarge")

Judaism is practised in all parts of the world, for example in a synagogue in
downtown [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai").

Countries such as the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"),
[Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel"), [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"), [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina
"Argentina") and [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") contain
large Jewish populations. Jewish religious practice varies widely through all
levels of observance. According to the 2001 edition of the [National Jewish
Population Survey](/wiki/National_Jewish_Population_Survey "National Jewish
Population Survey"), in the United States' Jewish community—the world's second
largest—4.3 million Jews out of 5.1 million had some sort of connection to the
religion.[131] Of that population of connected Jews, 80% participated in some
sort of Jewish religious observance, but only 48% belonged to a congregation,
and fewer than 16% attend regularly.[132]

Birth rates for American Jews have dropped from 2.0 to 1.7.[133] (Replacement
rate is 2.1.) Intermarriage rates range from 40–50% in the US, and only about
a third of children of intermarried couples are raised as Jews. Due to
intermarriage and low birth rates, the Jewish population in the US shrank from
5.5 million in 1990 to 5.1 million in 2001. This is indicative of the general
population trends among the Jewish community in the [Diaspora](/wiki/Diaspora
"Diaspora"), but a focus on total population obscures growth trends in some
denominations and communities, such as [Haredi Judaism](/wiki/Haredi_Judaism
"Haredi Judaism"). The [Baal teshuva](/wiki/Baal_teshuva "Baal teshuva")
movement is a movement of Jews who have "returned" to religion or become more
observant.

## Judaism and other religions

### Christianity and Judaism

Main article: [Christianity and Judaism](/wiki/Christianity_and_Judaism
"Christianity and Judaism")

See also: [Christianity and antisemitism](/wiki/Christianity_and_antisemitism
"Christianity and antisemitism") and [Christian–Jewish
reconciliation](/wiki/Christian%E2%80%93Jewish_reconciliation
"Christian–Jewish reconciliation")

[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") was originally a sect of
[Second Temple Judaism](/wiki/Second_Temple_Judaism "Second Temple Judaism"),
but the two religions [diverged in the first
century](/wiki/Split_of_early_Christianity_and_Judaism "Split of early
Christianity and Judaism"). The differences between Christianity and Judaism
originally centered on whether Jesus was the Jewish Messiah but eventually
became irreconcilable. Major differences between the two faiths include the
nature of the Messiah, of [atonement](/wiki/Atonement_in_Judaism "Atonement in
Judaism") and [sin](/wiki/Jewish_views_on_sin "Jewish views on sin"), the
status of God's commandments to Israel, and perhaps most significantly of the
[nature of God](/wiki/God_in_Judaism "God in Judaism") himself. Due to these
differences, Judaism traditionally regards Christianity as
[Shituf](/wiki/Shituf "Shituf") or worship of the God of Israel which is not
monotheistic. Christianity has traditionally regarded Judaism as obsolete with
the invention of Christianity and Jews as a people replaced by the Church,
though a Christian belief in [dual-covenant theology](/wiki/Dual-
covenant_theology "Dual-covenant theology") emerged as a phenomenon following
Christian reflection on how their theology influenced the Nazi
[Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The Holocaust").[134]

Since the time of the [Middle
Ages](/wiki/History_of_Christianity_during_the_Middle_Ages "History of
Christianity during the Middle Ages"), the [Catholic
Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") upheld the _[Constitution pro
Judæis](/wiki/Sicut_Judaeis "Sicut Judaeis")_ (Formal Statement on the Jews),
which stated

> We decree that no Christian shall use violence to force them to be baptized,
> so long as they are unwilling and refuse. ... Without the judgment of the
> political authority of the land, no Christian shall presume to wound them or
> kill them or rob them of their money or change the good customs that they
> have thus far enjoyed in the place where they live."[135]

Until [their emancipation](/wiki/Jewish_emancipation "Jewish emancipation") in
the late 18th and the 19th century, Jews in Christian lands were subject to
humiliating legal restrictions and limitations. They included provisions
requiring Jews to wear specific and identifying clothing such as the [Jewish
hat](/wiki/Jewish_hat "Jewish hat") and the [yellow badge](/wiki/Yellow_badge
"Yellow badge"), restricting Jews to certain cities and towns or in certain
parts of towns ([ghettos](/wiki/Jewish_ghettos_in_Europe "Jewish ghettos in
Europe")), and forbidding Jews to enter certain trades (for example selling
new clothes in medieval [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden")). Disabilities also
included special taxes levied on Jews, exclusion from public life, restraints
on the performance of religious ceremonies, and linguistic censorship. Some
countries went even further and completely expelled Jews, for example,
[England](/wiki/Edict_of_Expulsion "Edict of Expulsion") in 1290 (Jews were
readmitted in 1655) and [Spain](/wiki/Expulsion_of_the_Jews_from_Spain
"Expulsion of the Jews from Spain") in 1492 (readmitted in 1868). The first
Jewish settlers in North America arrived in the Dutch colony of [New
Amsterdam](/wiki/New_Amsterdam "New Amsterdam") in 1654; they were forbidden
to hold public office, open a retail shop, or establish a synagogue. When the
colony was seized by the British in 1664 Jewish rights remained unchanged, but
by 1671 [Asser Levy](/wiki/Asser_Levy "Asser Levy") was the first Jew to serve
on a jury in North America.[136] In 1791, [Revolutionary
France](/wiki/French_Revolution "French Revolution") was the first country to
abolish disabilities altogether, followed by [Prussia](/wiki/Prussia
"Prussia") in 1848. [Emancipation of the Jews in the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Emancipation_of_the_Jews_in_the_United_Kingdom "Emancipation of
the Jews in the United Kingdom") was achieved in 1858 after an almost 30-year
struggle championed by [Isaac Lyon Goldsmid](/wiki/Isaac_Lyon_Goldsmid "Isaac
Lyon Goldsmid")[137] with the ability of Jews to sit in parliament with the
passing of the [Jews Relief Act 1858](/wiki/Jews_Relief_Act_1858 "Jews Relief
Act 1858"). The newly united [German Empire](/wiki/German_Empire "German
Empire") in 1871 abolished Jewish disabilities in Germany, which were
reinstated in the [Nuremberg Laws](/wiki/Nuremberg_Laws "Nuremberg Laws") in
1935.

Jewish life in Christian lands was marked by frequent [blood
libels](/wiki/Blood_libel "Blood libel"), expulsions, [forced
conversions](/wiki/Forced_conversion "Forced conversion") and
[massacres](/wiki/Massacre "Massacre"). An underlying source of prejudice
against Jews in Europe was religious. Christian rhetoric and antipathy towards
Jews developed in the [early years of Christianity](/wiki/Apostolic_Age
"Apostolic Age") and was reinforced by ever increasing anti-Jewish measures
over the [ensuing centuries](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early Christianity").
The action taken by Christians against Jews included acts of violence, and
murder culminating in the [Holocaust](/wiki/Holocaust
"Holocaust").[138]:21[139]:169[140] These attitudes were reinforced in
Christian preaching, art and popular teaching for two millennia, containing
contempt for Jews,[141] as well as statutes which were designed to humiliate
and stigmatise Jews. The [Nazi Party](/wiki/Nazi_Party "Nazi Party") was known
for its [persecution of Christian Churches](/wiki/Kirchenkampf
"Kirchenkampf"); many of them, such as the Protestant [Confessing
Church](/wiki/Confessing_Church "Confessing Church") and the Catholic
Church,[142] as well as [Quakers](/wiki/Quakers "Quakers") and [Jehovah's
Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's Witnesses"), aided and
rescued Jews who were being targeted by the antireligious régime.[143]

The attitude of Christians and Christian Churches toward the Jewish people and
Judaism, have been changed mostly positive since [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). Pope [John Paul II](/wiki/John_Paul_II
"John Paul II") and the Catholic Church have "upheld the Church's acceptance
of the continuing and permanent election of the Jewish people" as well as a
[reaffirmation of the covenant](/wiki/Dual-covenant_theology "Dual-covenant
theology") between [God](/wiki/God_in_Christianity "God in Christianity") and
the Jews.[144] In December 2015, the [Vatican](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See")
released a 10,000-word document that, among other things, stated that
Catholics should work with Jews to fight antisemitism.[145]

### Islam and Judaism

Main article: [Islam and Judaism](/wiki/Islam_and_Judaism "Islam and Judaism")

Both Judaism and [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") arose from the patriarch
[Abraham](/wiki/Abraham "Abraham"), and they are therefore considered
[Abrahamic religions](/wiki/Abrahamic_religions "Abrahamic religions"). In
both Jewish and [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") tradition, the Jewish and
[Arab peoples](/wiki/Arabs "Arabs") are descended from the two sons of
Abraham—[Isaac](/wiki/Isaac "Isaac") and [Ishmael](/wiki/Ishmael "Ishmael"),
respectively. While both religions are [monotheistic](/wiki/Monotheism
"Monotheism") and share many commonalities, they differ based on the fact that
Jews do not consider [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus_in_Islam "Jesus in Islam") or
[Muhammad](/wiki/Muhammad "Muhammad") to be prophets. The religions' adherents
have interacted with each other since the 7th century when [Islam](/wiki/Islam
"Islam") originated and spread in the [Arabian
peninsula](/wiki/Arabian_peninsula "Arabian peninsula"). Indeed, the years 712
to 1066 CE under the [Ummayad](/wiki/Ummayad "Ummayad") and the
[Abbasid](/wiki/Abbasid "Abbasid") rulers have been called the [Golden age of
Jewish culture in Spain](/wiki/Golden_age_of_Jewish_culture_in_Spain "Golden
age of Jewish culture in Spain"). Non-Muslim monotheists living in these
countries, including Jews, were known as [dhimmis](/wiki/Dhimmis "Dhimmis").
Dhimmis were allowed to practice their own religions and administer their own
internal affairs, but they were subject to certain restrictions that were not
imposed on Muslims.[146] For example, they had to pay the [jizya](/wiki/Jizya
"Jizya"), a per capita tax imposed on free adult non-Muslim males,[146] and
they were also forbidden to bear arms or testify in court cases involving
Muslims.[147] Many of the laws regarding dhimmis were highly symbolic. For
example, dhimmis in some countries were required to wear [distinctive
clothing](/wiki/Yellow_badge "Yellow badge"), a practice not found in either
the [Qur'an](/wiki/Qur%27an "Qur'an") or the [hadiths](/wiki/Hadiths
"Hadiths") but invented in [early medieval](/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages "Early
Middle Ages") [Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad") and inconsistently
enforced.[148] Jews in Muslim countries were not entirely free from
persecution—for example, many were killed, exiled or forcibly converted in the
12th century, in [Persia](/wiki/Persia "Persia"), and by the rulers of the
[Almohad](/wiki/Almohad "Almohad") dynasty in North Africa and [Al-
Andalus](/wiki/Al-Andalus "Al-Andalus"),[149] as well as by the Zaydi imams of
Yemen in the 17th century (see: [Mawza Exile](/wiki/Mawza_Exile "Mawza
Exile")). At times, Jews were also restricted in their choice of residence—in
[Morocco](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco"), for example, Jews were confined to walled
quarters ([mellahs](/wiki/Mellah "Mellah")) beginning in the 15th century and
increasingly since the early 19th century.[150]

In the mid-20th century, Jews were expelled from nearly all of the Arab
countries.[151][152][153] Most have chosen to live in [Israel](/wiki/Israel
"Israel"). Today, antisemitic themes including [Holocaust
denial](/wiki/Holocaust_denial "Holocaust denial") have become commonplace in
the propaganda of Islamic movements such as [Hizbullah](/wiki/Hizbullah
"Hizbullah") and [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas"), in the pronouncements of
various agencies of the [Islamic Republic of
Iran](/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran "Islamic Republic of Iran"), and even in
the newspapers and other publications of [Refah Partisi](/wiki/Refah_Partisi
"Refah Partisi").[154]

### Syncretic movements incorporating Judaism

There are some movements that combine elements of Judaism with those of other
religions. The most well-known of these is [Messianic
Judaism](/wiki/Messianic_Judaism "Messianic Judaism"), a religious movement,
which arose in the 1960s,[155][156][157][158] that incorporates elements of
Judaism with the [tenets of Christianity](/wiki/Christianity#Beliefs
"Christianity").[158][159][160][161][162] The movement generally states that
[Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") is the Jewish Messiah, that he is one of the
[Three Divine Persons](/wiki/Trinity "Trinity"),[163][164] and that
[salvation](/wiki/Salvation_\(Christianity\) "Salvation \(Christianity\)") is
only achieved through acceptance of Jesus as one's savior.[165] Some members
of the movement argue that Messianic Judaism is a sect of Judaism.[166] Jewish
organizations of every denomination reject this, stating that Messianic
Judaism is a Christian sect, because it teaches creeds which are identical to
those of [Pauline Christianity](/wiki/Pauline_Christianity "Pauline
Christianity").[167]

Other examples of [syncretism](/wiki/Syncretism "Syncretism") include [Semitic
neopaganism](/wiki/Semitic_neopaganism "Semitic neopaganism"), a loosely
organized sect which incorporates [pagan](/wiki/Paganism "Paganism") or
[Wiccan](/wiki/Wicca "Wicca") beliefs with some Jewish religious practices;
[Jewish Buddhists](/wiki/Jewish_Buddhists "Jewish Buddhists"), another loosely
organized group that incorporates elements of Asian spirituality in their
faith; and some [Renewal Jews](/wiki/Jewish_Renewal "Jewish Renewal") who
borrow freely and openly from [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"),
[Sufism](/wiki/Sufism "Sufism"), [Native
American](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas") religions, and other faiths.

The [Kabbalah Centre](/wiki/Kabbalah_Centre "Kabbalah Centre"), which employs
teachers from multiple religions, is a [New Age](/wiki/New_Age "New Age")
movement that claims to popularize the [kabbalah](/wiki/Kabbalah "Kabbalah"),
part of the [Jewish esoteric tradition](/wiki/Jewish_mysticism "Jewish
mysticism").

"Paul was motivated by a Hellenistic desire for the One, which among other things produced an ideal of a universal human essence, beyond difference and hierarchy. This universal humanity, however, was predicated (and still is) on the dualism of the flesh and the spirit, such that while the body is particular, marked through practice as Jew or Greek, and through anatomy as male or female, the spirit is universal. Paul did not, however, reject the body—as did, for instance, the gnostics—but rather promoted a system whereby the body had its place, albeit subordinated to the spirit. Paul's anthropological dualism was matched by a hermeneutical dualism as well. Just as the human being is divided into a fleshy and a spiritual component, so also is language itself. It is composed of outer, material signs and inner, spiritual significations. When this is applied to the religious system that Paul inherited, the physical, fleshy signs of the Torah, of historical Judaism, are re-interpreted as symbols of that which Paul takes to be universal requirements and possibilities for humanity."

"When the term resurfaced in Israel in the 1940s and 1950s, it designated all Jews who accepted Christianity in its Protestant evangelical form. Missionaries such as the Southern Baptist Robert Lindsey noted that for Israeli Jews, the term _nozrim_ , "Christians" in Hebrew, meant, almost automatically, an alien, hostile religion. Because such a term made it nearly impossible to convince Jews that Christianity was their religion, missionaries sought a more neutral term, one that did not arouse negative feelings. They chose _Meshichyim_ , Messianic, to overcome the suspicion and antagonism of the term _nozrim_. _Meshichyim_ as a term also had the advantage of emphasizing messianism as a major component of the Christian evangelical belief that the missions and communities of Jewish converts to Christianity propagated. It conveyed the sense of a new, innovative religion rather that _[_[sic](/wiki/Sic "Sic") _]_ an old, unfavorable one. The term was used in reference to those Jews who accepted Jesus as their personal savior, and did not apply to Jews accepting Roman Catholicism who in Israel have called themselves Hebrew Christians. The term Messianic Judaism was adopted in the United States in the early 1970s by those converts to evangelical Christianity who advocated a more assertive attitude on the part of converts towards their Jewish roots and heritage."

"Messianic Judaism, although it advocated the idea of an independent movement of Jewish converts, remained the offspring of the missionary movement, and the ties would never be broken. The rise of Messianic Judaism was, in many ways, a logical outcome of the ideology and rhetoric of the movement to evangelize the Jews as well as its early sponsorship of various forms of Hebrew Christian expressions. The missions have promoted the message that Jews who had embraced Christianity were not betraying their heritage or even their faith but were actually fulfilling their true Jewish selves by becoming Christians. The missions also promoted the dispensationalist idea that the Church equals the body of the true Christian believers and that Christians were defined by their acceptance of Jesus as their personal Savior and not by their affiliations with specific denominations and particular liturgies or modes of prayer. Missions had been using Jewish symbols in their buildings and literature and called their centers by Hebrew names such as Emanuel or Beth Sar Shalom. Similarly, the missions' publications featured Jewish religious symbols and practices such as the lighting of a menorah. Although missionaries to the Jews were alarmed when they first confronted the more assertive and independent movement of Messianic Judaism, it was they who were responsible for its conception and indirectly for its birth. The ideology, rhetoric, and symbols they had promoted for generations provided the background for the rise of a new movement that missionaries at first rejected as going too far but later accepted and even embraced."
